features.Strategy_I: Secure boom to shore at an angle across bay entrance.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Bellingham or Anacortes.  No vehicle access.
features.Location: Inati Bay (East side of Lummi Island) WHA0314
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Inati Bay.
features.Resources_: Eelgrass, herring spawning, clam beds, cancer crab, seabirds, murrelets, pigeon guillemots and grebes.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at ferry terminal at Gooseberry Point, or at ferry terminal on Lummi Island.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from beach near the south end of the grass airstrip, south to the beach on the south end of the island.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Bellingham or Anacortes.  No vehicle access.
features.Location: Cove on West side of Eliza Island WHA0293
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Cove.
features.Resources_: Eelgrass, herring spawning, clam beds, cancer crab, seabirds, murrelets, pigeon guillemots and grebes.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at ferry terminal at Gooseberry Point, or at the Bellingham Marina.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across south entrance to slough.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Bellingham or Anacortes.  No vehicle access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of slough and protect water intake.
features.Resources_: Slough water intake.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Bellingham Marina.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the waterway under the Roeder Avenue/ Chestnut Street bridge.  A small workboat or skiff will be needed to deploy the boom.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Bellingham Marina; vehicle access from I-5 Lakeway Drive exit, go west to Holly Street and follow to waterway.
features.Location: Whatcom Creek (Whatcom Waterway  near the Roeder Avenue overpass) WHA0419
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil from moving up into the mouth of Whatcom Creek.
features.Resources_: Salmon stream, fish hatchery at Heritage Center.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Marine Heritage Center parking lot, or at the Bellingham Marina (WHA0414).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across creek mouth at railroad trestle.  Anchor to trestle pilings.  Can be deployed from land.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from ramp on south end of trestle; vehicle access from I-5 Fairhaven exit, go west on Fairhaven Parkway to 12th St., go north to Harris Ave., west to 6th St. and north to site.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of creek.
features.Resources_: Tidal stream, wetland habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at parking lot for boat ramp on south end of trestle.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in chevron configuration in front of gap in railroad trestle to lagoon.  Anchor to railroad trestle.  Flow through gap may be significant during tidal exchanges.  Will need a small workboat to set the anchor at the apex of the chevron.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the ramp at Padden Creek; vehicle access from I-5 Fairhaven exit, go west on Fairhaven Parkway to 12th St., go north to Harris Ave. and west to site.
features.Location: Lagoon at the Port of Bellingham Marine Park  WHA0433
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of lagoon
features.Resources_: Habitat for waterfowl and fish.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Port of Bellingham Marine Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in chevron configuration in front of gap in railroad trestle to lagoon.  Anchor to railroad trestle.  Flow through gap may be significant during tidal exchanges.  Will need a small workboat to set the anchor at the apex of the chevron.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the ramp at Padden Creek; no vehicle access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of lagoon
features.Resources_: Habitat for waterfowl and fish.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Padden Creek boat ramp.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in chevron configuration in front of gap in railroad trestle to isolate bay and creek.  Anchor to railroad trestle.  Flow through gap may be significant during tidal exchanges.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the ramp at Padden Creek; no vehicle access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of creek & North Chuckanut Bay.
features.Resources_: Waterfowl, clam beds, cancer crabs.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Padden Creek boat ramp.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across creek under the bridge on Drayton Harbor Road to collect on the southeast side of bridge.  A small workboat will be needed to deploy boom.
features.Site_Acces: Boat access from Blaine or Semiahmoo Marina.  Vehicle access from I-5 exit 274, go east and south on Blaine Road to Drayton Harbor Road, vac truck access from Drayton Harbor Road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion/ Collection - keep oil from moving up creek.
features.Resources_: Archaeological sites, eelgrass, herring spawning, salmonids, cancer crabs, shorebirds, seabirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from road at bridge.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at a similar angle to NPS-41 to close off the cove.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park or the Padden Creek ramp.  No vehicle access.
features.Location: Second Cove North of Pleasant Bay WHA0460
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of cove.
features.Resources_: Waterfowl, clam beds, eelgrass beds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Larrabee State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from Chuckanut Point to the opposite shore on the point to the northeast.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park or the Padden Creek ramp.  No vehicle access.
features.Location: First Cove North of Pleasant Bay WHA0461
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of cove.
features.Resources_: Waterfowl, clam beds, cancer crabs.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Larrabee State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from Chuckanut Point to the opposite shore on the peninsula to Governors Point.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park or the Padden Creek ramp.  No vehicle access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of bay.
features.Resources_: Waterfowl, clam beds, cancer crabs.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Larrabee State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the entrance of the cove.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park or the Padden Creek ramp.  Vehicle access to the ramp from I-5 exit 250, go west to Chuckanut Drive (Hwy 11) and follow it south to the park.
features.Location: Larrabee State Park, Wildcat Cove WHA0476
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Protect State Park, keep oil out of Wildcat Cove.
features.Resources_: State Park
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Larrabee State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the entrance to the creek in front of the railroad trestle.  Necessary only at high tide.  Can be deployed from land.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Larrabee State Park, boat access at high tide only.  Vehicle access from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Chuckanut Drive (Hwy 11), go north to site.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Colony Creek.
features.Resources_: Salmon stream, marsh habitat, waterfowl.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the end of the dirt road on the south side of the creek mouth.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across entrance to slough.  Can only be deployed at high tide, boat access only and area becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park ramp or from Anacortes; no vehicle access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Edison Slough.
features.Resources_: Marsh, salmonids, waterfowl
features.Staging_Ar: Stage in Edison or at the site for NPS-44.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom approx. 1000' down stream from bridge over Bayview- Edison Road.  Necessary only on high flood tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park ramp or from Anacortes; vehicle access from the staging area.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the Samish River.
features.Resources_: Marsh, salmonids, waterfowl
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along dirt road off the northeast side of the bridge on the Bayview- Edison Road.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across south entrance at the foot bridge.  The island between the north and south entrances is very low and may not block oil at extreme high tides.  May be able to deploy from land.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park ramp or from Anacortes; vehicle access from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview-Edison Road, to Samish Island Road, to private drive at south end of Alice Bay.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Alice Bay.
features.Resources_: Marsh, salmonids, waterfowl
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at private property at foot bridge, at Camp Kirby, or at Bayview State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the north entrance from the south shoreline on Scotts Point.  The island between the north and south entrances is very low and may not block oil at extreme high tides.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park ramp or from Anacortes; vehicle access from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview-Edison Road, to Samish Island Road, to road to Scots Point; access through private property.  May need helicopter support.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Alice Bay.
features.Resources_: Marsh, salmonids, waterfowl
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along road to Scotts Point, at Camp Kirby, or at Bayview State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from gravel beach south of light at an angle to deflect the oil into deeper water, or at an angle to collect oil with a skimmer at the end of the boom.  Current can be strong in this area, and boom should be tended.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Larrabee State Park ramp or from Anacortes; no vehicle access.
features.Location: William Point (200' South of Light) SKA0276
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Deflect oil out into open water or collect to prevent oil from moving north into Samish Bay.
features.Resources_: Samish Bay resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Camp Kirby or Bayview State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle out from beach about 1/4 mile north of  Semiahmoo Park and anchor to collect oil moving around Birch Point into bay.  Area subject to extreme adverse weather from northwest, deploy as much boom as possible.  Area is shallow and be
features.Site_Acces: Boat access from Blaine or Semiahmoo Marina.  Vehicle access from I-5 exit 274, go east and south on Blaine Road to Drayton Harbor Road, vac truck access at park.
features.Response_S: Collection - protect shoreline habitat and keep oil out of Drayton Harbor
features.Resources_: Archeological site (middens & burial), clam beds, eelgrass, sand lance, smelt, herring spawning, waterfowl concentrations.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Semiahmoo Park parking lot.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from end of spit at Camp Kirby to enhance natural collection area.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes; vehicle access from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview-Edison Road, to Samish Island Road and follow to camp, vac truck access to beach at camp.  Call the camp at 360-766-6060 for access.
features.Response_S: Collection - Prevent oil from moving up beach from the south.
features.Resources_: Protect resources to the north, Samish Bay.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Camp Kirby.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom to close off pocket marshes.  Pilings in front of marshes can be used to help anchor the boom.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes, you need a 7' plus tide to reach the area.  No vehicle access.  May need helicopter support.
features.Location: Pocket Marsh North of Joe Leary Slough (eastern shore of Padilla Bay) SKA0299
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of marsh.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh, waterfowl habitat, shorebirds
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Bayview State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in a chevron configuration with point of apex facing west.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes, you need a 7' plus tide to reach the area. There is road access on the south side of the slough through a private orchard (contact Merritt's Apples 360-766-6224 for access).  From I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview-
features.Response_S: Exclusion/ Collection - Keep oil out of marsh, Collect if feasible.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh, waterfowl habitat and sand lance larvae.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Bayview State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom to close off gaps between pilings in front of Oswald's salt marsh.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes, you need a 7' plus tide to reach the area.  Vehicle access from Bayview- Edison Road; from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview- Edison Road to site.  May need helicopter support.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - protect salt marsh behind crumbling pilings.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh, waterfowl habitat, shorebirds, oysters, Sand Lance larvae and State Park.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Bayview State Park, or along Bayview- Edison Road.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom along the length of the Sullivan Minor salt marsh, from Oswald's marsh to Persons Road.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes, you need a 7' plus tide to reach the area.  Vehicle access from Bayview- Edison Road; from I-5 exit 236, go west on Bow Hill Road to Bayview- Edison Road to site.  May need helicopter support.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of salt marsh.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh, waterfowl habitat, shorebirds, oysters, Sand Lance larvae and State Park.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Bayview State Park, or along Bayview- Edison Road.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in a chevron configuration with apex pointing north.  Deploy 400' for the west leg from the west side of the slough entrance directly north to the east end of Dike Island and to the apex anchor point in the main channel, which will also block
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Potential vehicle assess from the Padilla Bay bike trail on the east side of the slough, contact the Padilla Bay Reserve at 360-428-1558 for access.  May need helicopter support.
features.Location: Indian Slough (southern end of Padilla Bay)  SKA0331
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of slough.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh habitat, harbor seals, waterfowl and shorebird concentrations.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across western opening between Dike Island and the mainland.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  No vehicle access.  May need helicopter support.
features.Location: West end of Dike Island SKA0334
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of area behind Dike Island
features.Resources_: Salt marsh habitat, harbor seals, waterfowl and shorebird concentrations.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two 1300' legs of boom to form a chevron with the apex facing northwest.  Area is shallow and becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  No vehicle access.  May need helicopter support.
features.Location: Telegraph Slough (southern end of Padilla Bay) SKA0335
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of slough.
features.Resources_: Salt marsh habitat, harbor seals, waterfowl and shorebird concentrations.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two 500' booms on each side of the channel between the railroad trestle and the Highway 20 bridge to deflect the oil moving into the channel to collection sites along the shoreline.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20, go west to the boat ramp on the east side of the channel.  Vac truck access on both sides of the channel.
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Keep oil from moving into the Swinomish Channel.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two 500' booms on each side of the channel between the railroad trestle and the Highway 20 bridge to deflect the oil moving into the channel to collection sites along the shoreline.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20, go west to the boat ramp on the east side of the channel.  Vac truck access on both sides of the channel.
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Keep oil from moving into the Swinomish Channel.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two 500' booms on each side of the channel between the railroad trestle and the Highway 20 bridge to deflect the oil moving into the channel to collection sites along the shoreline.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20, go west to the boat ramp on the east side of the channel.  Vac truck access on both sides of the channel.
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Keep oil from moving into the Swinomish Channel.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two 500' booms on each side of the channel between the railroad trestle and the Highway 20 bridge to deflect the oil moving into the channel to collection sites along the shoreline.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20, go west to the boat ramp on the east side of the channel.  Vac truck access on both sides of the channel.
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Keep oil from moving into the Swinomish Channel.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle out from beach at Semiahmoo Park and anchor to collect oil moving around Birch Point into bay.  Area subject to extreme adverse weather from northwest, deploy as much boom as possible.
features.Site_Acces: Boat access from Blaine or Semiahmoo Marina.  Vehicle access from I-5 exit 274, go east and south on Blaine Road to Drayton Harbor Road, vac truck access at park.
features.Response_S: Collection - protect shoreline habitat and keep oil out of Drayton Harbor
features.Resources_: Archeological site (middens & burial), clam beds, eelgrass, sand lance, smelt, herring spawning, waterfowl concentrations.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Semiahmoo Park parking lot.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in chevron configuration in front of gap in railroad trestle to lagoon.  Anchor to railroad trestle.  Flow through gap may be significant during tidal exchanges.  Will need a small workboat to set the anchor at the apex of the chevron.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20, go west and exit at the Swinomish Casino, follow the dirt road along the railroad tracks on the east side of the trestle.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the marsh.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Starting at the boat ramp on the NE corner of March Point, deploy the boom along the shoreline 100-300 feet off the beach in a southerly direction, and bring the south end back in and anchor on the beach.  Add boom as it becomes available and time allows
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp, or from Anacortes.  Vehicle access from March Point Road.  Most of the beach becomes exposed at low tide, may need helicopter support.
features.Location: Northeast Shoreline of March Point SKA0362
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil off nearshore area and beach.
features.Resources_: Smelt spawning, herring, sand lance spawning, waterfowl, clam beds and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the boat ramp on March Point Road or at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle from the tip of March Point to collect oil moving along the beach from the west.  Extend boom to 1500' if it will improve collection efficiency and the currents allow it.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Swinomish Channel ramp, or from Anacortes.  Vehicle access on March Point Road.
features.Response_S: Deflection/ Collection - Prevent oil from moving around March Point to the east and south.
features.Resources_: Smelt spawning, herring, sand lance spawning, waterfowl, clam beds and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the boat ramp on March Point Road or at the Swinomish Channel boat ramp parking lot (under Highway 20).

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the entrance to the lagoon on the north shore of Crandall Spit.  Can be deployed from land.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access on March Point Road.
features.Location: Tidal Lagoon North of Crandall Spit SKA0370
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of tidal lagoon.
features.Resources_: Wetland habitat; waterfowl and shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along March Point Road.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across cove between the Equilon recreation area and Crandall Spit.  Cove becomes a mudflat at low tide.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access on March Point Road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of cove south and east of Crandall Spit.
features.Resources_: Herring and smelt spawning, dungeness crab, sand lance larvae.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along March Point Road or at the Equilon recreation area.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in a chevron configuration across the causeway opening .   Anchor to the Railroad trestle.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access on March Point Road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Prevent oil from entering south Fidalgo Bay.
features.Resources_: Seagrass, saltmarsh, smelt, herring, clams, crab, waterfowl, shorebirds, harbor seals.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along March Point Road or at the Equilon recreation area.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in a chevron configuration with a 1000' leg from the railroad causeway to the tip of Weaverling Spit, and a 3000' leg from the tip of the spit to the beach near Highway 20.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access from Fidalgo Bay Road.  From Highway 20, turn right onto Fidalgo Bay Road near the southwest end of Fidalgo Bay.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Protect shoreline habitat on Weaverling Spit.
features.Resources_: Herring & smelt spawning, sand lance larvae, hard shell clams, waterfowl & shorebird concentrations, seal haulouts.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from R/V Park on Weaverling Spit.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle from the beach at the picnic area in Cap Sante Park.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Potential vehicle access to picnic area on a pedestrian path.  From Highway 20 in Anacortes, continue north on Commercial Avenue to 4th Street, turn right to "T"Avenue and right again to the park.
features.Response_S: Collection - Keep oil from moving north into Guemes Channel.
features.Resources_: Fidalgo Bay and Guemes Channel resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the Cap Sante Marina parking lot.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the bay from the rocky point on the south side of the bay, to the beach to the northwest.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes or Bellingham.
features.Location: Long Bay (Southeast corner of Guemes Island) SKA0068
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the bay.
features.Resources_: Cultural/ archeological site.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from from Anacortes or Bellingham.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom along shore from the north end of "M" Avenue to "O" Avenue.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access from "N" or "M" Avenue.  From Highway 20 in Anacortes, continue north on Commercial Avenue to 4th Street, turn left and go one block to "O" Avenue.
features.Location: Pocket Beach on North Side of Fidalgo Island SKA0410
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil off of the pocket beach.
features.Resources_: Surf smelt spawning habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the north end of "N" or "M" Avenue.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy 1000' of boom at an angle from the east side of the harbor entrance to collect oil moving into the bay from the southwest, or deploy the boom from the west side of the harbor entrance to collect oil moving around the bay from the east.  Loop up to
features.Site_Acces: Boat access from the Birch Bay Village Marina.  Vehicle access from I-5 exit 270, go west to Birch Bay Drive and north to Birch Point Road.  Vac truck access from marina parking lot.  Gated entrance from Birch Point Road to Birch Bay Village, ask guard f
features.Response_S: Exclusion/ Diversion/ Collection - Keep oil out of Birch Bay, or keep oil off shoreline on Birch Point.
features.Resources_: Eelgrass beds, smelt and herring spawning just outside marina.  Sandlance larvae
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Birch Bay Village Marina.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom along shore from the north end of "H" Avenue to "I" Avenue at the ferry terminal (Guemes Island ferry).
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes.  Vehicle access from "I" Avenue at the ferry terminal.
features.Location: Pocket Beach on North Side of Fidalgo Island SKA0412
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil off of the pocket beach.
features.Resources_: Surf smelt spawning habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the ferry terminal on "I" Avenue.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from pilings at the ferry terminal to where road comes down to shore southeast of the terminal.  Run boom along outside piling line.  Keep boom outside mudflats so it does not dry out at low tide.  Anchor offshore, not to pilings.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Washington Park or Anacortes.  Vehicle access to the ferry terminal and to the beach on a road southeast of the terminal, from I-5 to Highway 20 west, follow signs to the ferry terminal.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of  Ship Harbor.
features.Resources_: Sand lance and surf smelt spawning habitat.  Large concentration of dungeness crabs, eelgrass beds, waterfowl, shorebirds, and sea urchins.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Washington Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy 200' of boom from shore to the Shannon Point daymarker, another 200' of boom from shore to the "submerged crib" (on chart), and 800' of boom parallel to shore to connect the two 200' legs (from the daymarker to the submerged crib).
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Washington Park or Anacortes.  Vehicle access to the lab from I-5 to Highway 20 west (follow signs to ferry), turn left onto Sunset Avenue and right onto Shannon Point Road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Protect seawater intake to lab and shoreline sites.
features.Resources_: Marine laboratory sea water intake, seabirds, and shoreline habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Washington Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the rocks at each end of the gravel beach in Washington Park (at the boat ramp).
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Washington Park or Anacortes.  Vehicle access to the park from I-5 to Highway 20 west (follow signs to ferry), turn left onto Sunset Avenue to park entrance.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil off of  Sunset Beach.
features.Resources_: Surf smelt spawning habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Washington Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle out from the cove west of Flounder Bay in Burrows Pass to collect oil moving along the shore from the west.  The current in Burrows Pass can be very strong and may require less boom to be deployed at a sharper angle.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from the Skyline Marina or the Washington Park ramp.  Vehicle access from I-5 to Highway 20 west (follow signs to ferry), turn left onto Sunset Avenue and left again onto Skyline Way, then turn right onto Hughes Lane to the cove.
features.Response_S: Diversion/ Collection - Prevent oil from moving into Burrows Bay.
features.Resources_: Sea urchins, abalone, Burrows Bay resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the Skyline Marina or Washington Park.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the narrowest part of the entrance to the harbor, from the rocky point on the south side of the harbor, directly north to the north shore.  Attach boom to the shore or trees, and anchor to maintain position.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes or Bellingham.
features.Location: Secret Harbor (Southeast Side of Cypress Island) SKA0164
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the harbor.
features.Resources_: Feeding habitat for marbled murrelets, eelgrass beds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from from Anacortes or Bellingham.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the ramp on the west shoreline.  No attachment point is available at the east bluff; anchor the boom in as near as possible to the bluff.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Anacortes or Bellingham.
features.Location: Eagle Harbor (Northeast Side of Cypress Island) SKA0185
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the harbor.
features.Resources_: Feeding habitat for marbled murrelets, eelgrass beds.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from from Anacortes or Bellingham.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at angle across creek mouth.  Can be deployed from land.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Tosco or BP docks.  Vehicle access from Birch Bay Drive.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of creek.
features.Resources_: State Park - archaeological sites, eelgrass, herring spawning, major waterfowl site.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along Birch Bay Drive, next to creek mouth.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle out from beach at state park to collect oil moving around Pt. Whitehorn past NPS-10 and NPS-11.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Birch Bay Village Marina or ramp at state park.  Vehicle access from I-5 exits 266 or 270, go west to Birch Bay Drive, vac truck assess from Birch Bay Drive.
features.Response_S: Diversion/ Collection - Protect shoreline habitat and state park area.
features.Resources_: State park, archeological sites, eelgrass, and herring spawning and major waterfowl site.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at Birch Bay State Park.

features.Strategy_I: Angle deflection boom upstream to direct oil to northeast side of bridge.  Collect with weir/disk skimmers; vac truck access.
features.Site_Acces: Road leads down to site off of SR 507
features.Location: Milwaukee Railroad Bridge - McKenna (just below SR 507 bridge) - River Mile 21.5
features.Response_S: Collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources.  Note location of elder care facility just upstream in McKenna
features.Staging_Ar: McKenna

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom to direct oil to the west side of the river where there is access from the dike road to recover the oil with portable disk/weir skimmers and vac trucks.
features.Site_Acces: Truck-accessible roads on the dikes.
features.Response_S: Collection
features.Resources_: Nisqually Wildlife Refuge; estuary resources
features.Staging_Ar: Nisqually Wildlife Refuge

features.Strategy_I: Deploy two parallel lengths of boom 100' each to close off Judson Slough.
features.Site_Acces: Boat launch at Luhr Beach, or Frank's Landing upstream
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of Red Salmon Creek slough.
features.Resources_: Red Salmon Creek
features.Staging_Ar: Nisqually Wildlife Refuge

features.Strategy_I: Enhanced skimming at mouth of Nisqually River
features.Site_Acces: Boat launch at Luhr Beach, or Frank's Landing upstream
features.Location: Mouth of Nisqually River - River Mile 0
features.Response_S: Enhanced Skimming
features.Resources_: Nisqually Wildlife Refuge; estuary resources

features.Strategy_I: If pipeline spill - close manual block valves located on both sides of crossing (700 barrel capacity in between).  Collect at the site if possible.
features.Site_Acces: Poor - steep banks limit access to river; river flow also limits booming.
features.Response_S: Pipeline shutdown; collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from residential streets to the south.

features.Strategy_I: Good access and shallow water, but swiftest flow in lower river will likely make booming ineffective.
features.Site_Acces: Road access on both sides.  3 rope bridge provides anchorage on both banks.
features.Response_S: Potential deflection/               collection site
features.Resources_: Downstream resources
features.Staging_Ar: Large broad area adjacent to river for parking, staging.

features.Strategy_I: Exclude from mouth of creek (or deflect if flow too great).
features.Site_Acces: Private property/     agricultural land; by small boat.
features.Location: Mouth of Yelm Creek - River Mile 13
features.Response_S: Exclusion
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations and habitat
features.Staging_Ar: Private property/     agricultural land.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy deflection boom just upstream of canal to direct into collection point at shore.  Note - if acceptable to power plant, could instead deploy boom just downstream of canal to deflect into canal for collection.
features.Site_Acces: Centralia Power Plant; boat.
features.Response_S: Collection
features.Resources_: Power plant intake; downstream resources
features.Staging_Ar: Centralia Power Plant (boat and some response equipment on-site).

features.Strategy_I: Close off mouth of intake canal to protect if spill on outside or contain spill from plant.
features.Site_Acces: Centralia Power Plant; boat
features.Response_S: Exclusion (and possible collection) - coordinate with SNR-5
features.Resources_: Power plant intake; downstream resources
features.Staging_Ar: Centralia Power Plant (boat and some response equipment on-site)

features.Strategy_I: Angle from current west bridge abuttment to upstream old east abuttment.  Collect at current west abuttment.
features.Site_Acces: Road access - note that cell phones do not work at this site.
features.Response_S: Deflection/           collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources (high value salmonid spawning area below this site)
features.Staging_Ar: On road on west side of bridge.  Note that Oly- mpic Pipeline Company has boom for this site in Olympia and Tacoma.

features.Strategy_I: Angle from north trestle upstream towards handicapped-access fishing site.  Collect with vac trucks/ skimmers.
features.Site_Acces: Road access.
features.Location: Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge - River Mile 4
features.Response_S: Deflection/                    collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources.  Note that tidal influence begins here.
features.Staging_Ar: Town of Nisqually.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy 3 lengths of boom, 400' each, just downstream of bridge.  Deploy vac truck on north bank to collect oil.
features.Site_Acces: Mounts Road - gravel roads on north bank (suitable for smaller trucks) lead to river.
features.Response_S: Deflection/                    collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources
features.Staging_Ar: North bank just downstream of bridge; apartment parking on south bank just downstream of bridge; Ft. Lewis Golf Course.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy 3 lengths of boom, 400' each, just downstream of bridge.  Deploy vac truck on north bank to collect oil.
features.Site_Acces: Mounts Road - gravel roads on north bank (suitable for smaller trucks) lead to river.
features.Response_S: Deflection/                    collection
features.Resources_: Downstream resources
features.Staging_Ar: North bank just downstream of bridge; apartment parking on south bank just downstream of bridge; Ft. Lewis Golf Course.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the creek somewhat upstream from mouth.  Tidal influence extends about 1/3 mile upstream. Need skiff.
features.Site_Acces: Via helicopter or Zodiacs.  See NPS for logging road access.  Possible to run skiff up Goodman Creek to first sandbar.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Goodman Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/ habitat, nesting eagles.
features.Staging_Ar: Open gravel area 1/4 mile upstream. Quillayute Prairie Airport or Forks airport.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the creek as close to the mouth as possible, as weather permits.  Move further up-stream if necessary.  A log jam typically forms at the mouth in the winter with a pool behind it.
features.Site_Acces: Via helicopter (not accessible in winter at high tide) or see NPS for logging road access.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Mosquito Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/ habitats; nesting eagles.
features.Staging_Ar: Kalaloch Lodge or quarries on 3600 road system.  Call NPS or Rayonier.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle to the NW from point east of the boat ramp on the south side; anchor to trees & rocks on both sides. An anchor at the mid-point will form a chevron, and oil can be collected at the boat ramp area.  Tidal influence to Oil City park
features.Site_Acces: Hoh Village road off HWY 101 to Hoh Indian Reservation.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Hoh River
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/ habitat; shorebirds; cultural resources (Hoh reservation on south side of river; National Park on north side).  1/4 mile north of river is important rocky intertidal coastline for Hoh Tribe.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the boat ramp area, from grass areas adjacent to Hoh Tribal centers, or from the Kalaloch Lodge.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across large pool behind driftwood line (about 1/8 mile above beach).  Pool is about 150' across and affected by extreme tidal conditions. During high flow conditions - deploy boom upstream about 100 yards between pool & Hwy 101.
features.Site_Acces: Ruby Beach parking lot 100 yds off HWY 101, 8 mi. N of Kalaloch.  6' wide trail from lot to beach.  Could accept heavy equip. w/ NPS permission.  Cedar Creek is approx. 20 yds from  foot of trail over wood piles.
features.Location: Cedar Creek at Ruby Beach JEF0803
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Cedar Creek at beach
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations and habitat, eagles, shorebirds, archaeological site at mouth.
features.Staging_Ar: Ruby Beach parking lot or main site at Kalaloch Lodge.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the mouth of the creek as weather permits.  Move strategy upstream if necessary.
features.Site_Acces: Behind Kalaloch Restaurant and store on HWY 101.  Caution - archaeological site at mouth
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Kalaloch Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations and habitat, archaeological site at mouth, NPS campground, drinking water intake above Highway 101.
features.Staging_Ar: Ranger station office; grass lot north of store (get permission from NPS). Helo landing zone permission from NPS in Kalaloch.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom as close to mouth as conditions allow (may need to back up to bridge).  Currents can exceed 3 knots; tides extend to village. Mouth subject to drastic changes. Contact Quinault Indian Nation for use of boats/ consultants, 360-276-4422.
features.Site_Acces: Downstream from town of Queets on Hwy 101.  Mouth not accessible by road.  Use shallow draft boat or helicopter.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Queets River
features.Resources_: Salt marsh.  Salmonid concentrations/      habitat.  Surf perch, flounder.  Abundant waterfowl and shorebirds.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Large field on south side of river; NPS campground on north side.  Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the mouth of the creeks below their confluence if the weather permits.  If not, back up as necessary and boom across each fork. Contact Quinault Indian Nation, 360-276-4422.
features.Site_Acces: Via Cape Elizabeth Road.  North fork bridge is O.K.; south fork bridge is unsafe. Contact Quinault Indian Nation for access, 360-276-4422.
features.Location: Whale Creeks (North and South Forks) GRA0008
features.Response_S: Protection - Keep oil out of creeks
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations and habitat; eagles.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Summer:  Deploy sorbent boom along salt marshes parallel to river (labor-intensive).  Winter: Deploy hard boom.  River mouth subject to drastic change; substantial flow year-round. Mouth may be natural collection point.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation, 3
features.Site_Acces: Helicopter preferred; trail access only from road.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Raft River
features.Resources_: Eagles and cormorants active on Tunnel Island, marine invertebrates, salmonid concentrations and habitat, salt marsh, fish rearing facility 1/4 mile upriver from mouth.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Summer:  Deploy sorbent boom along salt marshes parallel to river (labor-intensive).  Winter: Deploy hard boom.  River mouth subject to drastic change; substantial flow year-round. Mouth may be natural collection point.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation, 3
features.Site_Acces: Helicopter preferred; trail access only from road.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Raft River
features.Resources_: Eagles and cormorants active on Tunnel Island, marine invertebrates, salmonid concentrations and habitat, salt marsh, fish rearing facility 1/4 mile upriver from mouth.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across creek above first bend (at high tide, first bend is inaccessible).  Very little tidal influence.
features.Site_Acces: State Rt 109 (extension road on left just north of railroad creek bridge - 4 wheel drive only) or via helicopter. Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Camp Creek
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, salmonid concentrations and habitat, shellfish, eagles.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy hard boom at upper end of pond; place sorbent boom/ pom-poms at lower end of pond.  Mouth is 100' wide and shallow; collection area.  Little tidal influence.
features.Site_Acces: State Rt 109 (extension road on left just north of railroad creek bridge - 4 wheel drive only; half-mile trail to beach) or via helicopter. Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Duck Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations and habitat, waterfowl.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Stagger boom in  (3) 500' cascades angled from NW to SE to deflect oil to south shore pilings; significant anchor needs. Weather dependent- in winter, waves in beyond 101 bridge.
features.Site_Acces: No access to north shore.  Boat ramp upstream of tribal center.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion/          Collection - Keep oil out of Quinault River
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/       habitat; eagles on Cape Elizabeth; tribal cemetery/ cultural area.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Stagger boom in  (3) 500' cascades angled from NW to SE to deflect oil to south shore pilings; significant anchor needs. Weather dependent- in winter, waves in beyond 101 bridge.
features.Site_Acces: No access to north shore.  Boat ramp upstream of tribal center.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion/          Collection - Keep oil out of Quinault River
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/       habitat; eagles on Cape Elizabeth; tribal cemetery/ cultural area.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Stagger boom in  (3) 500' cascades angled from NW to SE to deflect oil to south shore pilings; significant anchor needs. Weather dependent- in winter, waves in beyond 101 bridge.
features.Site_Acces: No access to north shore.  Boat ramp upstream of tribal center.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion/          Collection - Keep oil out of Quinault River
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/       habitat; eagles on Cape Elizabeth; tribal cemetery/ cultural area.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas.

features.Strategy_I: Natural collection area in Grenville Bay - offshore skimming or onshore collection as needed.
features.Site_Acces: Single-lane, gated road to Loran Station (but 100' down to beach).  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Skimming/             collection
features.Resources_: Cultural resources (especially north side); nesting seabirds; shorebirds; mussels and other mollusks.
features.Staging_Ar: Loran Station

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across creek at bridge on Highway 109 as weather permits.  Creek width varies from 10' (spring) to 40' (winter).
features.Site_Acces: Directly off Hwy 109/parking area. Beach vehicle access on both sides of Wreck Creek, about 1.25 miles to north and 0.5 miles to south.  No boat landing site.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for guide and access, 360-276-4422.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Wreck Creek.
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, Coho salmon (April-August spawning), resident trout.  Cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Taholah - Quinault Indian Nation parking areas, or stage along road near creek.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the river mouth to a recovery point on south shore, anchor to pilings.
features.Site_Acces: Take 2nd St. off Hwy 109 across bridge; right on Railroad Ave, past 5th Ave to High Tide Resort. Right, then left into parking lot. 2 trails at end of lot lead to site. Road may wash out in winter.  Contact Quinault Indian Nation for access (2.25 miles u
features.Response_S: Exclusion/ Collection - Keep oil out of Moclips River
features.Resources_: North shore is on Quinault tribal land (marked with orange pilings). Smelt; salmonid concentrations and habitat; shorebirds; crab pots offshore; razor clams.
features.Staging_Ar: Numerous vacant lots along Railroad Ave.  County emergency may be able to provide assistance in obtaining permission to stage equipment.

features.Strategy_I: Backup OC-25a with 200' of boom across the river at the foot of 5th St. Anchor w/ steel stakes & to pilings.
features.Site_Acces: Take 2nd St. off Hwy 109 across bridge; right on Railroad Ave, right on 5th Ave to site.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Moclips River
features.Resources_: North shore is on Quinault tribal land (marked with orange pilings). Smelt; salmonid concentrations and habitat; shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Numerous vacant lots along Railroad Ave.  County emergency may be able to provide assistance in obtaining permission to stage equipment.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the south shore at an angle to the NE as the weather permits, recover oil at the east park boundary.  Anchor with stakes or Danforth anchors.  Low feasibilty.
features.Site_Acces: Take Main St. off 109 just north of the Joe Creek bridge.  Go west into town, turn left on 2nd to Park or Conference Center.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Joe Creek
features.Resources_: Pacific Beach State Park, salmonid concentrations and habitat, shorebirds, crab pots offshore, razor clams.
features.Staging_Ar: Pacific Beach State Park, Dept. of Defense Conference Center, U.S. Navy housing (contact Everett Naval Base)

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the east edge of the park at an angle to the NE across the creek.  Anchor with stakes or Danforth anchors.  Low feasibilty.
features.Site_Acces: Take Main St. off 109 just north of the Joe Creek bridge.  Go west into town, turn left on 2nd to Park or Conference Center.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Joe Creek
features.Resources_: Pacific Beach State Park, salmonid concentrations and habitat, shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Pacific Beach State Park, Dept. of Defense Conference Center, U.S. Navy housing (contact Everett Naval Base)

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the entrance to the cove at the creek mouth as the weather permits.  Cove becomes dry at low tide, and the creek is very shallow; 20' width. Back up boom with snares or sorbent sweeps across the creek at the culverts under Highway 109.
features.Site_Acces: Road by Iron Springs Resort off 109 approx. 3 miles north of Copalis Beach
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Boone Creek
features.Resources_: Estuarine habitat; shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Iron Springs Resort

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the river as far downstream as possible, but launch at Copalis Beach Food Bank boat ramp.  Tidal influence is greater than 1 mile.
features.Site_Acces: Copalis Beach food Bank Parking lot has boat ramp, 24 hr lighting  & boat dock for recovery operations. Need State Park permission to drive on beach.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Copalis River
features.Resources_: Marine birds, Coho salmon, shorebirds.
features.Staging_Ar: Parking lot of Copalis Beach Food Bank

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the mouth of the creek.  Do not take any action without approval of Makah Tribal authorities.
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Makah Tribal office complex. Road curves right.  Take left unimproved road to river edge near mouth.  Road can accept weight of heavy equipment.  Follow trail along the shore to the west about 1/4 mile to the creek.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of Waatch Creek.
features.Resources_: Salmonids, cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the dirt parking area along the river.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom near the mouth of the river as weather permits. Anchor with metal stakes on the south (Hobuck Beach) side, and rocks and trees on the north road access side. Can collect oil from the north side.  Difficult due to river current. Do not take an
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Makah Tribal office complex. Road curves right.  Take left unimproved road to river edge near mouth.  Road can accept weight of heavy equipment.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of Waatch River
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, waterfowl, nesting ospreys, salmonids, cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the dirt parking area along the river.

features.Strategy_I: Backup strategy for OC-4a.  Deploy boom across the river on the west side of the Waatch River Bridge across from the Makah Tribal office complex entrance.  Deploy boom in a chevron configuration with the apex to the west in the middle of the river channe
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Makah Tribal office complex. Turn left just before the office complex to bridge.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of Waatch River
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, waterfowl, nesting ospreys, salmonids, cultural resources.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the road at the bridge.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the end of the point on the west side of the river mouth to the shore directly to the east as weather permits.  Use trees or rocks as anchors, the river current at low tide is strong. Difficult to deploy at low tide due to river current.
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Neah Bay to just before Makah Tribal office complex, left across bridge, to site about 1/2 mi. past Bahobohosh Point curve.  Access to west side of river on private road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of Sooes River
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, waterfowl, salmonids, cultural resources, intertidal gathering area for tribe.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along the road next to the river.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom to enclose the marsh area on the east side of the river just south of OC-5a.  Contact Makah Tribal authorities.
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Neah Bay to just before Makah Tribal office complex, left across bridge, to site about 3/4 mi. past Bahobohosh Point curve.  Access to southwest end on private road.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - keep oil out of marsh
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, waterfowl, salmonids, cultural resources, intertidal gathering area for tribe.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along the road next to the river.

features.Strategy_I: Backup strategy for OC-5a.  Deploy boom from the southwest end of OC-5b at an angle across the river to the south and west to the west shore of the river.  The river current at low tide is strong.  Contact Makah Tribal authorities.
features.Site_Acces: SR 112 to Neah Bay to just before Makah Tribal office complex, left across bridge,  take right fork at quarry for approx. 3/4 mile, cross Sooes River bridge and continue west to sand dunes.  Take unimproved (private) road 1/2 mile north to the site.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Sooes River
features.Resources_: Shorebirds, waterfowl, salmonids, cultural resources, intertidal gathering area for tribe.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage on the west bank of the river.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the mouth of the river as weather permits.  Need zodiac/skiff. Contact Makah Tribal authorities.  All recovery equip. must be air transportable.
features.Site_Acces: SR112 to Lake Ozette Rd. turnoff onto Hoko Road to Ozette Ranger Sta. By helo only, or hike Mannys Prairie Trail 1.5 mi., 45 min walk.  Logging road to Duck Point (Seafield Creek) from Ozette, ends
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Ozette River
features.Resources_: Salmonids (depressed sockeye), eagles, river otters, archaeological sites at mouth.
features.Staging_Ar: Local logging landings - contact NPS.  Ozette Ranger station parking lot.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the creek as weather permits.  Pool behind logs during winter.  Flow generally less during summer.  All recovery equipment must be air transportable.
features.Site_Acces: West on La Push Road (highway 110), left onto 5000 Mainline logging rd. to 5200.  Thru gate, left to top of ridge, left on spur road to parking area.  Hike 1.5 mi.- Kayostola Beach, 20 min. Cedar Creek (no access at high tide).
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Cedar Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid habitat, recreation use, eagles, archaeological site at mouth, salt marsh behind Cedar Creek shelter.
features.Staging_Ar: Land at beach at Cedar Creek shelter, and on spur road off 5200 road.  Helo may land on beach during low tide.  Rayonier Logging Co. sites - Contact NPS.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom at an angle across the creek as weather permits.   Pool forms behind logs.
features.Site_Acces: Access via Rialto Beach, 200 feet north of parking lot. Access by foot, ATV, or helo (low tide).
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Ellen Creek
features.Resources_: Salmonid concentrations/ habitat.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the parking lot at Rialto Beach.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the south end of the marina seawall (leaving the marina entrance open for vessel traffic) to the south and west to the backside of the breakwater north of James Island. Strategy is necessary only during flood tide and high slack; river f
features.Site_Acces: West on La Push Road (highway 110), continue west in La Push to USCG.  Consider local knowledge from gill netters in area.
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Quillayute River (severe weather may require that the strategy be placed near the Dickey River inlet due to debris, storm surges)
features.Resources_: Bald eagles at mudflats at mouth of Dickey River; fisheries resources; shorebirds; hatcheries up stream.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the boat ramp in LaPush.  Can also use the Quileute Tribal baseball field or Quillayute Prairie Airport.  When in La Push, Corps. of Engineers dredge may be useful.

features.Strategy_I: Back-up for OC-9a.  Deploy boom from the south end of Mora parking lot (backside of Rialto Beach) to the north end of the LaPush marina across from USCG. Strategy is necessary only during flood tide and high slack; river flow will prevent oil from enteri
features.Site_Acces: West on La Push Road (highway 110), continue west in La Push to USCG. To reach N side of river, turn right to Mora Rd.  Road ends at Rialto Beach parking lot across river from USCG. Boat ramps on both sides. Consider local knowledge from gill netters in
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of Quillayute River (severe weather may require that the strategy be placed near the Dickey River inlet due to debris, storm surges)
features.Resources_: Bald eagles at mudflats at mouth of Dickey River; sloughs/ estuary habitat; fisheries resources; shorebirds; hatcheries upstream.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage at the boat ramp in LaPush.  Can also use the Rialto Parking Lot, Quileute Tribal baseball field or Quillayute Prairie Airport.  When in La Push, Corps. of Engineers dredge may be useful.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the entrance to the cove.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Friday Harbor or Anacortes.  Vehicle access from Orcas Island ferry, go west and north from the ferry to the Horseshoe Highway, then go west on Deer Harbor Road to Deer Harbor.
features.Location: Deer Harbor - Cove on the West side of the Harbor  (Southwest side of Orcas Island)  SNJ1189
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of the cove.
features.Resources_: Waterfowl concentrations, small stream at the head of the cove.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage from the Deer Harbor County dock (SNJ1196), or from Friday Harbor or Anacortes.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom from the west side of the harbor just south of the bridge at an angle to the southeast to the east side of the harbor.  Collect oil with a vac truck from the road on the west side of the harbor.
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Friday Harbor or Anacortes.  Vehicle access from Orcas Island ferry, go west and north from the ferry to the Horseshoe Highway, then go west on Deer Harbor Road to Deer Harbor.
features.Location: Deer Harbor - Lagoon at far North end of the Harbor  (Southwest side of Orcas Island)  SNJ1190
features.Response_S: Exclusion/ Collection - Keep oil out of inner harbor/ lagoon, collect with vac truck at road.
features.Resources_: Dungeness crab, oysters, sea urchins, and mudflats.
features.Staging_Ar: Stage along road on west side of harbor, from the Deer Harbor County dock (SNJ1196), or from Friday Harbor or Anacortes.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom in a chevron configuration from the dock on the west side to the Johnston's property on the east side.  This location keeps the boom in water even at low tide, most of bay becomes a mudflat at low tide.  Be aware of two pinnacle rocks near th
features.Site_Acces: By boat from Friday Harbor or Anacortes.  Vehicle access from Orcas Island ferry, go west and north from the ferry to the Horseshoe Highway and follow to Olga and Buck Bay.
features.Location: Buck Bay  (Orcas Island, east side of East Sound)  SNJ0829
features.Response_S: Exclusion - Keep oil out of bay.

features.Strategy_I: Deploy boom across the narrowest part of the entrance to Port Discovery.  Port Discovery becomes a mudflat at low tide.  Deploy boom along the eastern edge of the mudflat so the boom remains in water at low tide.

name: Washington State Department of Ecology, Marine Oil Spill Booming Strategies, Washington, 2003
description:
Abstract:
    Booming strategies for Geographic Response Plans for the Washington marine areas and Lower Columbia River. Includes the major tribs to the Lower Columbia in Oregon. 
Purpose:
    To show generalized location and placement of booms in the event of a major oil spill. In the Map Document "Explore GRPs.mxd", the Layer name is "Booming Strategies." The layer is set to draw at: 1:200,000 and larger. Labels are set to draw at the same scale.

author.source: Dale Davis, WA Department of Ecology
